text: 1 CP312 Algorithm Design and Analysis I LECTURE 3: CHARACTERIZING RUNNING TIME Simplifying the Running Time Expression â€¢ Consider the following running time: ğ‘‡ ğ‘› = ğ‘0 + ğ‘1ğ‘› + ğ‘2ğ‘›2 + ğ‘3ğ‘›3 + â‹¯ + ğ‘ğ‘‘ğ‘›ğ‘‘ â—¦ Too complicated â—¦ Too many terms â—¦ Difficult to compare two expressions of the same form â—¦ Do we really need that many terms? â€¢ Example: ğ‘‡ ğ‘› = 10ğ‘›3 + ğ‘›2 + 40ğ‘› + 800 â—¦ If ğ‘› = 1000, then ğ‘‡ ğ‘› = 10,001,040,800 whereas 10ğ‘›3 = 10,000,000,000 â—¦ If we approximate and drop all but the ğ‘›3 term the error is 0.01% â—¦ So, it is worth simplifying a complexity expression to get the core factor in that expression 2 Simplifying the Running Time Expression 3 â—¦ Only the dominant terms of a polynomial matter in the long run â—¦ Lower-order terms fade to insignificance as the problem input size increases â—¦ We care more about scalable algorithms than those for specific small-size inputs Growth Rate of Running Time â€¢ For any given running time function, in order to write it in the best way that represents the general growth rate. 1. We consider only the most dominant term â—¦ Keep the fastest growing term and remove the lower-order terms 2. Constant coefficients are removed â—¦ These constants represent language- or machine-dependent overhead â—¦ Growth rate not affected by constant coefficients â€¢ Examples: â—¦ ğ‘‡ ğ‘› = 100ğ‘› + 10 5 is considered a linear function â—¦ ğ‘‡ ğ‘› = 80ğ‘›2 + 50ğ‘› + 10 is considered a quadratic function 4 Asymptotic Complexity â€¢ Finding the exact complexity, ğ‘‡ ğ‘› = number of primitive operations, of an algorithm is difficult. â€¢ Therefore, we approximate ğ‘‡(ğ‘›) by a function ğ‘”(ğ‘›) in a way that does not substantially change the magnitude of ğ‘‡(ğ‘›) â—¦ The function ğ‘”(ğ‘›) is sufficiently close to ğ‘‡(ğ‘›) for sufficiently large values of the input size ğ’. â€¢ This "approximate" measure of efficiency is called asymptotic complexity. â€¢ Thus, the asymptotic complexity measure does not give the exact number of operations of an algorithm, but it shows how that number grows with the size of the input. â—¦ This gives us a measure that will work for different operating systems, compilers and CPUs. 5 For large enough ğ‘›: ğ‘‡ ğ‘› â‰ˆ ğ‘”(ğ‘›)Asymptotic Complexity â€¢ Three main types of asymptotic complexity expressions: 1.
